text: Truth Decay is a 2018 book by Jennifer Kavanagh and Michael D. Rich published by the RAND Corporation. It discusses the diminishing role of facts and analysis in American public life. The book covers Truth Decay's four trends: * increasing disagreement about facts and analytical interpretations of facts and data * a blurring of the line between opinion and fact * the increasing relative volume, and resulting influence, of opinion and personal experience over fact * declining trust in formerly respected sources of factual information.The era of "truth decay": 12 things we still don't know about our weird time, Laura Hazard Owen, Nieman Lab, 2018-01-26 The authors differentiate Truth Decay from "fake news" and "post-fact/truth". The book has spawned studies and panel discussions worldwide.Truth Decay: Exploring the diminishing role of facts and analysis, United States Studies Centre, University of Sydney, 2018-08-22 RAND communications analyst Sonni Efron first suggested the term "truth decay" in this context.https://www.rand.org/pubs/research_reports/RR2314.html ==References== ==External links== * Truth Decay: An Initial Exploration of the Diminishing Role of Facts and Analysis in American Public Life Category:2018 non-fiction books
